awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Exocube 2 - A Cubesat to Measure In-situ the Global Distribution of Light Species Densities in the Exosphere
awd_abstract_narration:
A small satellite with a miniature mass spectrometer (referred to as INMS) as the centerpiece instrument and including all telemetry, communication and attitude control systems has been designed, the instrumental parts fabricated, and what remains is the integration of these parts required to achieve delivery by the spring of 2017. The purpose of this CUBESAT satellite mission is to provide in-situ densities of atmospheric species near 500 km, on a global scale. This satellite, named "EXOCUBE 2", follows directly on the "EXOCUBE" mission that had a similar scientific scope. EXOCUBE suffered communication problems due to an antenna deployment system failure, and one attitude control system gravity boom also failed. Nevertheless, the key science package, the neutral and ion mass spectrometer, did perform as expected and a small amount of data retrieved indicated the efficacy of that instrument, which flew for the first time, on EXOCUBE. 

The rationale justifying a RAPID proposal for EXOCUBE 2 is that this satellite mission is manifested to fly on the NASA Educational Launch of Nanosat (ELaNa) launch queue in the fall of 2017.  Achieving this date would require the ExoCube-2 satellite delivery to take place within the spring of 2017. The proposed work would rapid assemble and integrate the mass spectrometer and satellite bus to meet this demanding one-year schedule. The very short development time and minimal cost is made possible by the legacy experience and materials left over from the previous flight of the EXOCUBE satellite that unfortunately failed owing to the failure of the deployment of the telemetry transmitting antenna.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
ExoCube 2 is a collaboration between NASA Goddard and the PolySat lab at Cal Poly SLO. It is a nanosatellite that is designed to provide 90 days of data on [O], [H], [He], [O+], [H+], [He+], [NO+] and total ion densities.  The spacecraft was developed by undergraduate and graduate students at Cal Poly over the course of three years.  It underwent extensive integrated testing with the payload and numerous environmental tests to build confidence that it would survive the ride to orbit.  ExoCube 2 was launched on ELaNa-XX mission January 13th, 2021.


 

Initial spacecraft acquisition and operations took place according to plan.  Spacecraft heath telemetry and thumbnails from deployment imagery were downloaded while ExoCube 2 was within range of Cal Poly.  However, after a few weeks of operations it was discovered that an anomaly with the solar power generation resulted in the batteries always having a small, persistent discharge.  Analysis of archived testing data indicated that this anomaly was not present prior to the spacecraft being launched.  A detailed plan to address the unexpected state was developed and tested using a ground clone of the spacecraft.  The attempts to apply the workarounds to the flight unit were hampered by the communication challenges that nearly discharged batteries presented.  Ultimately the spacecraft was not able to enter science mode or take any science observations.



 


Last Modified: 02/08/2022
Modified by: John M Bellardo

por.por_txt_cntn:
ExoCube 2 is a collaboration between NASA Goddard and the PolySat lab at Cal Poly SLO. It is a nanosatellite that is designed to provide 90 days of data on [O], [H], [He], [O+], [H+], [He+], [NO+] and total ion densities.  The spacecraft was developed by undergraduate and graduate students at Cal Poly over the course of three years.  It underwent extensive integrated testing with the payload and numerous environmental tests to build confidence that it would survive the ride to orbit.  ExoCube 2 was launched on ELaNa-XX mission January 13th, 2021.




 

Initial spacecraft acquisition and operations took place according to plan.  Spacecraft heath telemetry and thumbnails from deployment imagery were downloaded while ExoCube 2 was within range of Cal Poly.  However, after a few weeks of operations it was discovered that an anomaly with the solar power generation resulted in the batteries always having a small, persistent discharge.  Analysis of archived testing data indicated that this anomaly was not present prior to the spacecraft being launched.  A detailed plan to address the unexpected state was developed and tested using a ground clone of the spacecraft.  The attempts to apply the workarounds to the flight unit were hampered by the communication challenges that nearly discharged batteries presented.  Ultimately the spacecraft was not able to enter science mode or take any science observations.
